Introduction

Transient synovitis, a self-limiting inflammatory condition of the joint synovium, classically presents with hip pain in well-appearing young children following a viral illness.  This condition is a diagnosis of exclusion and must be distinguished from potentially life-threatening conditions such as septic arthritis.

Pathogenesis



Transient synovitis is the most common cause of acute hip pain in children.  This benign condition is characterized by inflammation of the synovium (inner lining of the joint).  Effusion develops in the joint space, and the increased pressure results in pain, decreased range of motion, and limp.  Although the cause is unknown, it typically occurs in children age 3-8 following a mild viral illness (eg, gastroenteritis, respiratory infection) or, less commonly, after minor trauma involving the hip (eg, sports injury).  In some cases, no preceding trigger is identified.

Clinical presentation



Patients with transient synovitis classically present with acute, unilateral hip pain that develops 1-2 weeks after a viral illness (eg, upper respiratory infection).  Referred pain to the groin, thigh, or knee may occur, and a minority of patients have bilateral symptoms.  Fever is typically absent (or low-grade, <38.5 C [101.3 F]).



Examination shows a well-appearing child who may hold the hip flexed, abducted, and externally rotated to relieve pressure in the joint space; range of motion is therefore often limited, particularly during attempted internal rotation of the hip joint.  Knee examination is normal.  An antalgic gait (limp) is common, although patients can bear some weight on the affected leg.

Differential diagnosis



Transient synovitis is a diagnosis of exclusion and must be distinguished from other conditions that cause hip pain in young children, particularly those that are life-threatening or require emergent treatment.



  • Septic arthritis (
    figure 1
    ):  Bacteria invade the synovial space, usually via hematogenous spread, resulting in severe joint pain.  Patients typically appear ill, have high fever, and refuse to bear weight on the affected extremity.  Range of motion (both active and passive) is significantly restricted due to pain and inflammation.  Leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers are typical.
  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (
    figure 2
    ):  Excessive shearing forces result in a fracture at the proximal femoral physis (growth plate).  Presentation includes hip (or referred knee) pain, limited internal hip rotation, and a limp; however, a slipped capital femoral epiphysis typically has an insidious onset and usually occurs in adolescents who are obese.  X-ray demonstrates anterosuperior displacement of the proximal femur diaphysis relative to the femoral head.
  • Legg-CalvÃ©-Perthes disease:  An idiopathic disruption of blood supply to the femoral head results in avascular necrosis of the affected hip joint, most commonly affecting children age 3-12.  Patients often have hip pain and a limp; however, onset is gradual, and pain is often worse, rather than relieved, during hip abduction.
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA):  Autoantibody-induced inflammation develops within the synovial space, causing chronic (â‰¥6 weeks) joint swelling and deformity.  Certain subtypes also cause rash and fever (eg, systemic JIA), whereas others typically involve many joints, including the knees, wrists, and hands (eg, polyarticular arthritis).  Isolated hip involvement is rare.

Evaluation



Children age 3-8 who have features consistent with acute, unilateral hip inflammation (eg, pain, limited range of motion) should undergo laboratory evaluation to help distinguish transient synovitis from septic arthritis (

).  In transient synovitis, white blood cell count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein levels are normal or only mildly elevated due to lack of infection or significant inflammation.



Further evaluation (eg, x-ray, ultrasonography, arthrocentesis) is required in patients who are toxic appearing or nonâ€“weight-bearing or who have signs of marked inflammation (eg, temperature >38.5 C [101.3 F], white blood cell count >12,000/mm3, erythrocyte sedimentation rate >40 mm/hr or C-reactive protein >2 mg/dL).  Hip x-ray in transient synovitis is normal, and ultrasonography revealing small, bilateral hip effusions (even in patients with unilateral symptoms) is nonspecific but consistent with the diagnosis.  Although a unilateral effusion can also be seen with transient synovitis, concomitant signs of marked inflammation warrant arthrocentesis in such cases.

Diagnosis



Transient synovitis is a diagnosis of exclusion based on the following:



  • Acute, unilateral hip (or referred groin, thigh, or knee) pain with absent (or low-grade) fever in a well-appearing child age 3-8.
  • Decreased internal hip rotation on examination and presence of antalgic gait with the ability to bear some weight on the affected extremity.
  • Normal (or mildly elevated) white blood cell count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein on laboratory evaluation.

Management and prognosis



Treatment of transient synovitis includes rest and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (eg, ibuprofen).  This inflammatory condition is self-limited, and symptoms usually resolve within 1-2 weeks; patients can return to full activity as tolerated.



There is a low risk for recurrence (<15%), which also follows a benign course.

Summary



Transient synovitis (

) is a benign, self-limiting condition of the hip that occurs in children age 3-8.  Manifestations include acute hip pain and limp, often following a viral illness.  Patients are generally well-appearing and afebrile without laboratory evidence of significant inflammation.  Treatment is supportive (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs).
